questions.question_text: An engineer must collect all Cisco CleanAir alarms in a central location for archival purposes. Which device is configured for collection?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
To collect and archive Cisco CleanAir alarms in a centralized location, Cisco Prime Infrastructure (PI) is the appropriate tool. Cisco Prime Infrastructure is a network management platform that provides comprehensive monitoring, troubleshooting, and reporting capabilities for Cisco wireless networks. It can collect and store CleanAir data, including alarms, for historical analysis and archival purposes.

Cisco Prime Infrastructure aggregates CleanAir data from multiple Wireless LAN Controllers (WLCs) and Access Points (APs), providing a centralized view of air quality, interference, and alarms.

It also offers long-term storage and reporting capabilities, making it ideal for archival purposes.
 (WLC - Wireless LAN Controller): The WLC manages CleanAir data locally but does not provide centralized archival capabilities.

comments.content: But they do not ask where do would you go to get the report, the question is which device collects the data, so I think D perhaps seeing that the controller collects the data.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I am going to say "b" as mentioned. On a 9800 WLC, APs are shown in real time, the Air Quailty report are on APs at that moment. Once an AP goes down you can no longer find it on the WLC. You have to then go to Prime or Catalyst Center to view history information.

Selected Answer: D
Might be D according to the following:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/8-3/config-guide/b_cg83/b_cg83_chapter_011001.html

"Role of the Cisco Wireless LAN Controller in a Cisco CleanAir System

 Collects and processes air quality reports from the access point and stores them in the air quality database. The Air Quality Report (AQR) contains information about the total interference from all identified sources represented by the Air Quality Index (AQI) and summary for the most severe interference categories."

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which two items must be supported on the VoWLAN phones to take full advantage of this WLAN configuration? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
The expedited bandwidth request feature enables CCXv5 clients to indicate the urgency of a WMM traffic specifications (TSPEC) request (for example, an e911 call) to the WLAN. When the controller receives this request, it attempts to facilitate the urgency of the call in any way possible without potentially altering the quality of other TSPEC calls that are in progress.

https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/wireless/controller/7.4/configuration/guides/system_management/config_system_management_chapter_010000.html#ID3249

in the exhibit the Expedited bandwidth is not selected so TSPEC is not valid

You must enable admission control (ACM) for CCXv4 clients that have WMM enabled.
The WMM standard is a subset of IEEE 802.11e.
C+D

I thing CD
The 802.11e, WMM, and Cisco Compatible Extension specifications help balance and prevent the overloading of a cell with audio streams. CAC determines whether there is enough channel capacity to start a call; if not, the phone can scan for another channel
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/8-1/Enterprise-Mobility-8-1-Design-Guide/Enterprise_Mobility_8-1_Deployment_Guide/Chapter-9.html

I would argue TSPEC and 802.11e but it seems kind of redundant since TSPEC is defined in the 802.11e standard. That said WMM is not related to CAC and Power Save is not involved in the shown configuration and SIFS is definitely not a feature that needs to be supported. So going with Cisco's "the best answer" I'd say TSPEC and 802.11e.
I would say the answer is A + D

Selected Answer: B
It is either B or C

FlexConnect is designed for branch deployments where APs can continue functioning even if they lose connectivity to the centralized WLC. To ensure users remain connected when the WLC connection fails but 802.1X authentication is still available, the best option is Authentication Local / Switch Local.

Authentication Local → The AP handles 802.1X authentication locally, allowing clients to authenticate even if the WLC is unreachable.
Switch Local → The AP forwards client traffic directly to the local switch, reducing reliance on the WLC for data plane operations.
Why not the other options?
A. Authentication Central / Switch Central → Requires WLC connectivity for both authentication and switching. If the WLC fails, clients will be disconnected.
C. Authentication Central / Switch Local → Still relies on the WLC for authentication, meaning users will be disconnected if the WLC is unavailable.
D. Authentication Local / Switch Central → Authentication works locally, but traffic is still sent back to the WLC, which can create problems if the WLC is down.

Selected Answer: C
To ensure that users remain connected to the FlexConnect APs even if the connection to the Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) fails, the Authentication Central/Switch Local configuration should be implemented. This configuration provides the following benefits:

Authentication Central: User authentication (e.g., 802.1X) is handled by the WLC when it is reachable. This ensures centralized control over authentication policies.

Switch Local: Traffic is forwarded locally at the AP, even if the WLC is unreachable. This allows users to stay connected and continue accessing local resources during a WLC outage.

This setup is ideal for branch offices where maintaining connectivity during WLC failures is critical.

Selected Answer: B
To ensure that users remain connected to the FlexConnect APs even if the connection to the Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) fails, the Authentication Central/Switch Local configuration should be implemented. This configuration provides the following benefits:

Authentication Central: User authentication (e.g., 802.1X) is handled by the WLC when it is reachable. This ensures centralized control over authentication policies.

Switch Local: Traffic is forwarded locally at the AP, even if the WLC is unreachable. This allows users to stay connected and continue accessing local resources during a WLC outage.

This setup is ideal for branch offices where maintaining connectivity during WLC failures is critical.

Selected Answer: B
C is also not wrong as it mention that existing users should stay connected. B would be the best options for new sessions as far as 802.1X stays online

questions.question_text: An engineer must deploy FlexConnect APs to a branch office. If the connection to the WLC fails and 802.1X authentication is available, users must stay connected to the AP. Which FlexConnect state should be implemented?

choices.B:
switchport mode access
switchport access vlan 25
choices.C:
switchport mode trunk
switch trunk native vlan 25
choices.D:
switchport mode access
switchport access vlan 25
switchport access voice vlan 25
choices.A:
switchport mode trunk
switchport trunk allowed vlan add vlan 25

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
To meet the requirement of locally switching client traffic for a new SSID mapped to an onsite voice VLAN (VLAN 25), the switch interface connecting to the APs must be configured as a trunk port. This allows the AP to handle multiple VLANs, including the voice VLAN, for locally switched traffic.

switchport mode trunk: Configures the port as a trunk port, enabling the AP to carry traffic for multiple VLANs.

switchport trunk allowed vlan add vlan 25: Ensures that VLAN 25 (the voice VLAN) is allowed on the trunk port, allowing the AP to map the SSID to this VLAN.

This configuration is necessary because:

The AP needs to support both the existing centrally switched traffic and the new locally switched traffic for the voice SSID.

The trunk port allows the AP to tag traffic with the appropriate VLAN IDs, including VLAN 25 for voice devices.

questions.question_text: A company has an existing Cisco wireless solution deployed to a remote branch location with centrally switched control and data traffic. A new solution is needed to locally switch client traffic when Wi-Fi is used. A new SSID that is used only for voice devices must be mapped to an onsite voice VLAN named VLAN 25. Which configuration on the switch interface that connects to the APs meets the requirement?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
E is certainly wrong, as all APs currently registered to the WLC will receive this global configuration too, not just future associations.

Selected Answer: CD
C.D are the right answers

choices.B: APs joined to this WLC can be accessed through the default credentials.
choices.C: APs inherit the credentials from this global configuration on the WLC, unless specifically overridden on an AP level.
choices.D: Cisco Discovery Protocol is globally enabled, and it can be turned off for a specific AP, if desired.
choices.E: The changes on this page only apply to APs that would associate to the WLC in the future.
choices.A: Global configuration for APs is AP group-specific in the WLC.
